author: alexis.franck
title: From Plastic Waste 2 Social Housing
description: Slumdogs and plastic pollution in Ecosystems are social and environmental issues growing with the urbanization across the African continent.

assessments.note: No details are given as to how Cardano is actually going to be used. Smart contracts are mentioned, however they are not yet available on Cardano.
The proposal could be a lot more detailed. It is like a broad aproach at the moment. Maybe find a litte more concrete solution.

The idea is good because it intends to act on the problem of pollution, focusing on the use of plastic, and seeking to develop ecological housing for the marginalized people in this community. In addition to being beneficial to the locality, the project relates to the Cardano community through smart contracts, which would use blockshain technology, and the creation of tokens for various purposes.

The proposal is noble, unique, and has a good chance for positive impact in multiple ways for the society. The proposal also addresses the problem of poor urban planning in the large number of countries.

I think that the idea behind this proposal has enormous merit and promise. The proposed deployment of Ssocial housing campaigns using Plastic Waste-2-Brick technology sounds like an amazing approach for utilizing the advantages of Cardano - by tying in different actors involved in this space. 

We are not assessing the idea alone, however. 

The proposal itself still seems to be in the idea stage and that is a weakness to me - as it is still not sufficiently well defined to distinguish it from just an idea.

The proposer specifies that the Cardano smart contracts vehicle can be used to certify several components of the implementation, but the precise details of this remains sketchy at best and the smart contracts/Cardano integration seems to come as an afterthought. Still, the proposal's impact on Africa as presented could be important - not completely sure about its impact on Cardano - as it is not exactly clear to me how much traction would the Cardano blockchain have in this sense - as I do not see that the risks have been addressed sufficiently.
The proposal is inline with the challenge's mission by offering ways to capitalize on waste while also cleaning up the waste. This is a worthwhile combination of great things.

At first glance I couldn't find a connection between this proposal and the challenge. After reading the attachment, which is not mentioned in the proposal, that became more clear, yet I don't see the need for several for-profit organisations already operating in several countries around the globe applying for a fund in Project Catalyst, but rather getting in direct touch with the Cardano Foundation.
The link of the project to Cardano is very weak. The only connection would be, that the tasks could be paid in ADA.

I love the idea of a catalyst fund using proven plastic waste construction methods (bricks).  There are also proven small-scale methods to convert plastic waste into other useful objects.  Unfortunately the proposal offers very little information as to how the program would be implemented and the exact nature of the Cardano integration. Without more information it is difficult to understand the potential impact on the challenge criteria.

Although this proposal has merit in regard to African development it fails to address the implementation of the Cardano ecosystem into the project. Simply stating that 'smart contacts can be used' is not enough to explain how the proposal will help drive the adoption of Cardano in Africa. The idea of the Cardano Plastic Unit - the main connector is not fleshed enough to understand its actual implementation - the economics and workings of this concept would be needed to fully understand how this proposal can have an impact in Africa using Cardano.

The proposer has domain experience in the physical product, however no information is given on experience in connecting this to a blockchain. There are no real detail in the plan on what would actually be done.

If a proposal mentions partners it should provide a little more details about them. It would help as well if the team behind this proposal would introduce themself a litte more.

Then a clear budget which includes what is spent on what task is always beneficial. If you are serious about this project maybe re-do the proposal and propose again for the next fund with a more detailed proposal

It was not very clear  in the text who the authors of the project would be. In document attached we can see: It is the E&S group, which, according to what has been said, has a direct relationship with social and environmental programs, specifically dealing with the issue of plastic.  There is a short summary about the group and what it does. However, I felt that this information was still on a very theoretical plane. For example: It is not possible to understand who are the people involved in this group, what are their professional backgrounds, previous experiences. Also in the document, we can even see who the group's partnerships are, but no space is dedicated to getting to know their members better.
Es-communication and their partners have impressive credentials and have undertaken a substantial number of works in sustainable development. The project is likely to be implemented successfully.

I am not sure about the proposer's qualifications and ability to tackle a project of this scope and magnitude (it does not identify a microenvironment for implementation - rather it tackles Africa as a whole). The proposal does not include detailed information about skills, qualifications, prior experience, how will the smart contracts be developed, applied and tested, etc...
The proposed budget is not broken down into components, nor is a step-by-step timetable provided. The proposal seems still to be heavy on the idea part, but light on the implementation aspects and the nitty-gritty details. As the saying goes, the devil is in the detail and unfortunately this proposal suffers from a lack of detail - making it less convincing. 
If the proposer and his team (if there is a team) are well-skilled and knowlegable in the fields that are required, the proposal would have benefited from a detailed presentation of their qualifications, as well as how long have they been working together, plus the budget details and a clear timetable. 
Effectively, I find it impossible to determine whether the budget is reasonable to achieve the set goals and the challenges and risks have not been addressed sufficiently.

The team sounds impressive, and the plan is sound as well. However, key details on how the incentives will work are missing. What isn't clear is how $20,000 will help achieve the goals. Is there a market place where all of the infrastructure is already developed, but an incentivisation structure is all that is missing? then yes this sounds feasible. Does the production facility need to be built? if so what's the plan? There is significant risk of failure if the infrastructure for processing and moving materials is not yet built. Would love to see a business plan with numbers that are reasonable.

The information in the project description is not detailed. Additional facts can be found in the attachment, but that is not hinted at in the main text. Even so, after reading several pages, it hasn't gotten very clear what they are asking the money for. It's not a big amount, so is it more as a way to advertise themselves? There is definitely a good idea behind this and I would like to see it implemented on the African continent in the near future, however the proposal needs to be re-written for the Cardano community rigours.

The proposed solution is already successfully applied. The linked presentation is convincing. I deduct one star because it is not stated, what will be with the funds. I am sure, that everything related to the Waste-2-Brick solution could be done by the proposer, but providing a feasibility-score for tasks that are not really specified is hard.

The proposers appear to have experience and connections with the waste-2-brick technology. To make this proposal more feasible, I suggest they acquire some  partners 1) on the ground in Africa  2) experienced in business proposals and 3) experience in blockchain technology.  While some partnerships are mentioned, no relevant details are provided.  I don't see a feasible implementation with Cardano as realistic from the current proposal
The proposal lacks details on the team skillset, relevant experience, and Key performance indicators for the project implementation.

E&S Eurocentre appears to be a Brussels based co-working space - there is no mention of past experience in the deployment of social housing or details or links about the technical partners. There are details about connections to NGOs, governments in African countries. It is difficult to gather from the presented information if the proposer has the necessary experience or knowledge of what would be needed to implement successfully. Much greater detail is needed to be communicated about the team and partners.
There is not enough information on what is actually going to be done andhow this would involve Cardano.
The proposal is quite vague and it is hard to asses it. A well elaborated roadmap, budget and team-introduction would help a lot, maybe a risk-assessment as well.

Regarding the theoretical basis of the project, we have a lot of detailed information in the attached document. Even a graph, which visually demonstrates what this process involving plastic would look like. It is very interesting to build things like this, in a more direct and visual way, because it helps laypeople to better understand the functioning of a whole. However, I missed a more detailed planning regarding the act of making it happen. How this whole theory would be put into practice, set goals, worked on predetermined deadlines... In addition, they also did not include how the financing money would be used, which is a very important part to be analyzed.

The progress is easily auditable. The proposal aims to use the DEFI vehicle to ease transactions in the ecosystem generated by these plastic waste management programs. It will be possible to measure accurately the volume of micro-entrepreneur transactions that the proposed system will carry out.

Unfortunately, my impression is that the success of this proposal will be hard to audit as it does not include critically needed pieces of information that are required for any outside audit or auditing team. The timetable is simply not present as far as I can see.  The moving pieces of the project are not clearly presented and the budgetary allocation seems to be just a lump sum for everything - which will make it hard to assess whether the project is progressing according to plan. Furthermore, the cost of developers and smart contract development is unclear and the proposal would benefit from clarifying all these aspects. 
While the problem is presented in a manner that can be understood, the proposed solution is more akin to a framework for resolution, without a specific implementation plan that would inspire confidence in the success of the proposal. The inclusion of specific metrics and deliverables would have strengthened the proposal immensely.

the proposal doesn't include clear goals on what the  adoption rate is expected to be, and doesn't identify how the budget will help the team achieve their goals. What is presented is a framework but lacks detail.

The project is already running on other continents, so expanding to the African continent is a natural next step. They have a good idea behind it, yet strictly as a Catalyst project it's lacking too many informations to be able to clearly assess it. If they really need the funding to start organising the project in Africa, I would suggest re-writing it and applying for a future fund.
There are not milestone, KPIs or other aspects specified, that would allow to audit the projects. It is not known, what exactly would be funded with the requested amount of money.
no breakdown of fund allocation is provided. No metrics for success and relevant time frames are provided. I do not see this as an auditable proposal as presented.

The project lacks a roadmap that shows how this proposal can be implemented. 
Please develop a step-by-step plan of action.

There is no breakdown of the proposed budget of $20000, why this amount and how will it be spent? These two questions would need to be answered in order fulfill the question of Auditability of the funds provided. There is a section in the attached document "Volumes and financial forecasts" which does provide some details on the effect of the proposal on waste and possible economic outcome of the Cardano Plastic Units that could be used to audit the success of the proposal but it is not clear over how long the provide funds will cover or the period.

solution: Deployment of Social housing campaigns using Plastic Waste-2-Brick proven technology, and social embedded waste collection programs.
experience: E&S supports social and environmental programs with a specific focus on Plastic waste. The Plastic-2-Brick tech is validated on large scale.
